See "Section 4.3"

comments.author: nicorusti

Observation from Ramon Keller (libc):

See "Section 3.1 Trust Model"

Each ISD has to implement more than one CP-PKI to adhere to the goal of having no single point of failure in the control plane. Smaller ISDs therefore have to bear high operational costs if they have to operate several PKIs on their own.

In order to reduce costs, it must be possible and explicitly desired that trust centres that operate CP-PKIs can offer their services to multiple ISDs. (Multi-tenant wise.)

Self-Signed certificates just add some identity information to a public key for easier identification. issues.title: SCION Certificate Specification deviates from permitted data types for individual RDN attributes
issues.author: knmeynell
issues.body:
Observation from Ramon Keller (libc):

See "2.2.1. Basic Fields: SCION-Specific Constraints and Conditions"

Issuer and Subject DN - The SCION Certificate Specification Standard is based on [RFC5280] and [X.509], but deviates from the permitted data types for individual RDN attributes. While the general X.509 standard, as described in ITU-T X.520, prescribes the data type PrintableString for countryName and serialNumber, SCION generally requires UTF-8 coding. Such contradictions to the standard can lead to complications in various contexts, such as directory services and their schemas.

Validity - The draft states that GeneralizedTime is not permitted and must be rejected, allowing only UTCTime. However, this appears to conflict with RFC 5280, which mandates the use of GeneralizedTime for dates on or after the year 2050.

issues.title: Signing TRCs using EKU does not align with semantics of timestamping
issues.author: knmeynell
issues.body:
Observation from Ramon Keller (libc):

See "2.2.2 Extensions"

The Root CA certificates must contain the timestamping OID in its extended key usage extension but must not set the digitalSignature flag in the key usage extension. It is understood that the root CA certificate must include an additional key usage beyond keyCertSign to support TRC signing, but requirement to include the Extended Key Usage (EKU) OID for timestamping raises questions.

According to RFC 5280, the EKU extension is intended for End Entity certificates, and the act of signing TRCs does not align with the original semantics of timestamping. It is unclear why this functionality is not based on the digitalSignature key usage alone.

issues.title: Mandating that certificates be retrieved from TRC payload limits interoperability with existing CMS libraries
issues.author: knmeynell
issues.body:
Observation from Ramon Keller (libc):

See "Section 3.1.3.1"
```
   *  SignedData sequence:

      -  The certificates field MUST be left empty.  The certificate
         pool used to verify a TRC update is already specified in the
         certificates field of the predecessor TRC's payload (see also
         Section 3.1.2.2.11).
```

Requiring the Certificates field in the CMS `SignedData` structure to be empty, and instead mandating that certificates be retrieved from the Certificates field of the TRC payload, significantly limits interoperability with existing CMS libraries. Most CMS implementations expect the signing certificate to be present within the Certificates field of the SignedData structure. As a result, signature verification logic would need to be re-implemented, or the parsed CMS structure would need to be modified by injecting the certificates from the TRC payload into the Certificates field—despite this field not being part of the signed data—solely to satisfy library expectations.

According to the current definition, only the AS certificate is returned by the CA. Returning the Control Place CA certificate together with the CP AS certificate is one solution. The other option would be to provide and support the AIA extension in the certificates, but AIA is certainly not the most efficient solution.

issues.title: Substitution to Certificate Revocation
issues.author: knmeynell
issues.body:
Observation from Ramon Keller (libc):

See "Section 1.4.2"

Certificate revocation is described as unreliable and compensated for with the concept of short-lived certificates. Instead of withdrawing certificates that are no longer trustworthy, certificates that are still valid are reissued again and again.

With a certificate validity period of three days and a grace period of approx. 1.5 days, the entire stock of valid certificates is renewed every 1.5 days. This places extremely high demands on the reliability of a CP-PKI and therefore also a high load on the CP-PKI systems. Although no comparison to loads on streaming portals, this concept is certainly not energy-efficient.

This load increases linearly with the growth of ASes within an ISD, and it will probably be the large, general-purpose ISDs that are orientated towards a lower trust level and cannot afford the financial or human resources to operate a highly available CP-PKI. Could the criticality of CP-PKI become a disabler of SCION technology?

SCION delegates authorization to the CP-PKI, but certificates should only be used to authenticate. Currently, whoever possesses an AS Certificate is enabled to communicate but this keeps the discussed attack window open.

Does SCION implement other mechanisms to exclude malicious participants? Something like a PCB-blocking, decided and issued by the core ASes as such an incident is reported to them? What are the consequences to leaf nodes attached to any blocked / not re-certified node in general?

issues.title: CA certificates - evaluate use of link certificates
issues.author: knmeynell
issues.body:
Observation from Ramon Keller (libc):

See "Sections 2.1.2, 2.1.3 & 2.1.4"

Root Certificates (added to the TRC) are recommended to be valid for just one year only. This requires that a Root CA is replaced by its successor every year in a TRC ceremony. (Sensitive TRC update).

Would it be conceivable to introduce the concept of link certificates to transfer the trust from one root CA to another in order to reduce the effort involved in sensitive TRC updates?

Concept taken from ICAO Doc 9303 part12:

A specific link certificate is signed by the Root CA key which is to be decommissioned. The public key contained within the link certificate is the one of the new root key. The link certificate technically looks like a certificate issued to a sub-CA, but it is used differently. It has a shorter lifetime and must not be used to sign any other certificates. It is solely used to transfer the trust from the old root key to the new key. The old key confirms the rise of the new one.

The current strategy to let the CA sign the new TRC with the old CA key also works, but it requires a TRC update. On the other hand, link certificates would not require a TRC update, but the clients would need to maintain the list of link certificates from the root in the TRC down to the current CA certificate which also introduces some complexity.

issues.title: Operational Considerations
issues.author: knmeynell
issues.body:
Observations from Ramon Keller (libc):

**AS Certificate creation:**

Initial AS certificates are still described as to be submitted out of band. Is there any progress of the process in this respect since the SSFN implementation?

**Short certificate lifetime:**

The SCION draft still recommends very short lifetimes for Root CA and Issuing CA certificates of 1 year or 11 days (!), respectively. Renewal in such short lifetimes will kill any operations team running certain commercial products. These products are sold in conjunction with HSM and much longer certificate lifetimes than those that were e.g. implemented for SSFN. Anybody wanting to implement the recommended lifetimes needs to look for a capable solution.

**Control Plane AS Certificates:**

The recommended validity of 3 days is fair, but then the initialization processes must be stable and effective. Could SIX provide any experience based feedback on how much the end users relied on a longer duration for initial AS certificates when onboarding to SSFN?

**Processes**

The draft talks a lot about the technical elements of a CP-PKI, but not much about processes the PKI operators have to implement. or the regulations.

**Cost of Ownership**

The range extends from simple technical systems focussing on stable network communication at affordable costs to highly secure environments that place great value on reliable network communication in combination with a high level of data protection. Those with higher security requirements should be willing to bear the higher security costs through secure processes, but only those with technical requirements should be exempt from additional costs as far as possible.

**High availability in CAs**

1. Must the CAs of an ISD offer backup CA services to all the other PKIs in the ISD?
2. What if a single PKI fails to operate?
3. To cope with this single point of failure, it should be specified that the subscribers could quickly switch over to one of the other PKIs to be able to renew their certificates on time.
4. How is the subscriber database synchronized among the different backup CAs, as without a specification the SCION world will face incompatible implementation-specific approaches.

issues.author: knmeynell
issues.body:
Brian Trammell's comments...

The SCION Control Plane PKI draft (PKI; draft-dekater-scion-pki-10) defines the trust architecture that underpins the entire SCION system. It establishes a framework for authenticating control plane messages and path information through a novel, domain-based trust model. It specifies the cryptographic underpinnings constituting ISDs and the trust relationships within them. A Trust Root Configuration (TRC) acts as the trust anchor for an ISD, containing the root certificates needed to validate a hierarchy of CA and AS certificates, as well as the policies for its own evolution through regular and sensitive updates.

This approach provides what the document calls "trust agility," allowing different parts of the network to operate under distinct, self-contained trust environments, a significant departure from the global, monolithic trust models of the web PKI. Instead of traditional certificate revocation lists, the CP-PKI relies on relatively short-lived certificates and TRC updates to manage compromised keys. The PKI is the foundation upon which the SCION Control Plane (CP) builds its secure beaconing and path discovery mechanisms, and by extension, provides the trust necessary for the Data Plane (DP) to forward packets along authenticated paths.

The document is well put together (aside from a few nits) and explains the functionality of the PKI well. The questions I have mainly concern the operational consequences of the certificate management periods at each level of the hierarchy down from the TRC: the grace and overlap periods seem from first principles to be sufficient to manage availability risk due to higher-frequency key rotation, but it would be interesting to see how this plays out in reality (I can't really think of a way to analyze this except in production, or with a questionably-applicable simulation).

Further "out there", I'd also be interested in exploring how the PKI itself could be incrementally applied to routing security with the existing interdomain control plane (this idea is inchoate enough that I can't really seriously elaborate it further in the context of a review).


```suggestion
The relying party must be able to discover and obtain new or updated cryptographic material. For the control plane messages, this is simplified by the observation that the sender of a message (e.g. of a path construction beacon during path exploration or a path segment during a path lookup) always has all the cryptographic material to verify it. Thus, the receiver can always immediately obtain all the cryptographic material from the message originator.
As the corresponding PKI messaging thus only occurs when the control plane is already communicating, these requests to obtain cryptographic material are not prone to additional denial of service attacks. We therefore refer to {{I-D.scion-cp}} for a more detailed description of DoS vulnerabilities of control-plane messages.

For certificate renewal, on the other hand, this does not apply.
Denial of Service on the CA infrastructure or on the communication links from the individual ASes to the CA, could be used by an attacker to refuse victim ASes from  renewing their certificates. After the short-lived certificates expire, an AS is effectively banished from the network.
To address this risk, the individual isolation domains and/or CAs should have policies and processes to renew certificates out-of-band.
```
